title: Experimental Methods in Neuroscience
description: This course will examine the experimental techniques currently available to neuroscientists. It will explore the kinds of information obtainable in studying phenomena ranging from electrophysiological recordings of individual neurons, to metabolic processes, ensembles of neurons, to behavioral output. Techniques to be covered include microscopic methods (light, electron), electrophysiology (extracellular/ intracellular single cell recordings, multiple cell recording methods, brain slices), macroscopic methods (ERP, MEG, TMR), metabolic measures (microdialysis, biosensors, MR spectroscopy), imaging approaches (optical tomography, PET, SPECT, functional MRI), and interventional techniques (lesions, cortical stimulation, knockout genetics, surgery, drugs). The knowledge gained from each of these approaches, the limitations of the methods, and future developments will be considered. This is a lecture course and students will be evaluated through oral class presentations in a journal club format. No prior familiarity with these methods is needed in order to participate.
